Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mixing at Stream and River Confluences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will use field data for small and large river confluences in the United States and Europe and a numerical model of river flow to examine the mechanisms that enhance or inhibit mixing water, solutes, contaminants and sediment immediately downstream of river confluences. The project will address the processes through which solutes and suspended solids are mixed in river systems, a major issue that geomorphologists, hydrologic scientists, and scholars in related fields have addressed in recent decades. The project will provide fundamental theory-based insight into the factors that promote or inhibit mixing at river confluences and the role of different hydrodynamic mechanisms in mixing. Knowledge gained from the project will benefit society by identifying mechanisms by which potential contaminants are dispersed when moving through river networks. This knowledge will also be useful for management of river ecosystems by showing how mixing influences the biogeochemical conditions on which ecosystems within confluences and downstream of these locations depend. The investigators will collaborate with the National Great Rivers Research and Education Center, Lewis and Clark Community College, and the National Mississippi River Museum to enhance pre-collegiate and public education, involve undergraduate students, and disseminate project findings. Educational materials sharing new knowledge about river mixing and the scientific methods used to generate those insights will be developed and included in K-12 student-learning and teacher-training activities. The project will involve interdisciplinary education and training of two graduate students, and work with an international collaborator in Germany will enhance infrastructure for research and education.

Past research on this topic has shown that some confluent flows mix almost completely within the immediate vicinity of the confluence, whereas others remain generally unmixed hundreds of channel widths downstream of a confluence. The factors governing whether a confluence is characterized by large or small amounts of mixing have yet to be determined. This project will identify the main mechanisms that control flow structure; generation of large-scale turbulence; and mixing of water and suspended sediment within confluences. The project will determine how these mechanisms change as the shape, form, incoming flow characteristics, and size of confluences vary. The investigators will conduct detailed field investigations of mixing at several small stream confluences with different geometrical configurations of the incoming tributaries. They also will develop and validate numerical models of flow and mixing. The detailed field investigations will generate data for rigorously evaluating and refining the predictive capabilities of the numerical model of confluence mixing over a range of flow conditions and confluence geometries. Predictions from simulations will be compared to available data for other confluences to ascertain the capabilities of the model to accommodate scale effects and differences in confluence form and size. The refined and calibrated model will be used to perform numerical experiments to evaluate mixing at confluences over a broad range of environmental conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
River confluences are primary locations for mixing of water, solutes, contaminants and sediment in natural river systems. Understanding of fluvial processes at confluences is important for determining river mixing downstream of individual confluences and at the scale of entire drainage networks.

The primary achievement of this work was to provide novel insight into the mechanisms that control mixing and transport at river confluences by taking advantage of state-of-the-art, eddy-resolving numerical simulations. These simulations allowed discovery of new physics especially related to the conditions that lead to the formation of streamwise oriented vortical cells in the vicinity of the interface between the two streams and how stratification effects induced by unequal temperatures of the incoming streams affects mixing between the two streams. Another main achievement of the present project was to clarify how some of the main geometrical and flow parameters (e.g., angle between the two streams, channel curvature, temperature difference between the streams, flow shallowness) defining the confluence affect the position and structure of the shallow mixing layer and the spatial development of mixing between the two streams. This was achieved via a series of numerical experiments conducted in confluences of simplified geometry in which only one parameter was varied at the time.  The flow data provided by the simulations showed reasonable agreement to field measurements conducted as part of the same study. Moreover, the numerical simulations provided additional information and knowledge not easily, or impossible to obtain, from field experiments (e.g., distribution of the bed shear stress and relationship betweeen large scale coherent structures and sediment entrainment processes). As such the present study made an important contribution to understanding the mechanisms responsible for the development of the confluence scour hole.  

With the knowledge acquired in simple confluences, flow and transport processes at several natural river confluences were investigated. The study considered three main types of confluences, each of them posing a set of new challenges in terms of understanding flow hydrodynamics and mixing.  Simulations of the KRCS confluence in Illinois allowed understanding temperature induced stratification effects at confluences with a concordant bed. Simulations of the confluence of Ebro and Segre Rivers in Spain allowed understanding how mixing processes change at confluences with a high degree of bed discordance where the shallow mixing layer originating at the confluence apex is very weak.  Finally, simulations of a mountain river confluence on the Rhone River revealed that flow structure at mountain river confluences can be very different to the one observed at confluences where the Froude number of the two tributaries is much smaller than one. Data from the simulations was used to explain bed erosion processes for this important category of river confluences.

The main intellectual merit of the present research was to examine in a comprehensive and systematic way the role that confluences play in mixing of the flow originating in the incoming tributaries and to identify the conditions that result in an increase in mixing. For example, it was shown that temperature induced stratification can act toward an increase of mixing in some cases.  Most of the new mixing mechanisms observed for cases where stratification effects are important are not visible from the free surface, thus the great utility of 3-D numerical simulations to reveal the conditions (e.g, confluence geometrical and flow parameters) that promote or inhibit mixing and the role of the different hydrodynamic mechanisms in mixing.

The present research identified several mechanisms by which potential contaminants are dispersed when moving through river networks. The research results are also useful for optimizing the management of river ecosystems by showing how mixing influences the biogeochemical conditions on which ecosystems within confluences depend. Research results are being incorporated into several undergraduate and graduate classes. The grant supported two PhD students. As part of the project the students interacted with several of the leading research programs active in the area of confluence hydrodynamics and transport processes. The main findings of the project were already presented at several major international symposia and meetings, including in special sessions dedicated to confluence flows. Research results are also used to educate the general public about the importance of confluences to natural river networks.
